Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2012 08:51AM jgisme wrote: Thank you for all the responses! I tested negative on the BRCA gene.  That was huge relief!   However, because of my age, I'm seriously leaning toward a bliateral.  I'm 36 and have an 8 month old daughter.  I found my lump while I was breastfeeding.  A bilateral seems extreme, and I'm not comfortable taking a perfectly good breast.  Yet my chances were pretty low of getting this cancer to begin with; and it seems recurrence is more common than I thought it would be.  In addition, I can't stand the thought of testing every 6 months--I have always had lumpy breasts and I wonder how many mammos I will go through before I get a call telling me they've found something.  While that doesn't mean it'll be cancer, I abhor the thought of putting my husband or myself through all this again.   I should mention that when I originally posted this, I was under the impression the cancer was lobular.  I spoke with the doctors office and found out that right now they have decided it is invasive ductal--so I'm not sure where we got our wires crossed.  In any case, I don't have a grade yet (obviously) and I don't know what stage.  I've had a biopsy, a mammogram, an ultrasound and an MRI, all of which indicate stage II.   As I said, I'm not comfortable taking a perfectly good breast, yet I'm not comfortable with testing and worry on the other side.  (Sigh)  I'll keep praying.  I'm scheduled for surgery the 11th, but I know I can change my mind before then.  It's also an irreversible decision.   Any suggestions pre-surgery?  Maybe I should post a whole new topic on that...?
Posts.Title: Unilateral vs. Bilateral MX: regrets? jgisme GreenEyes57

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2012 01:42AM jgisme wrote: Wildrumara, Thank you for your reply and for sharing your story.  I, too, consider myself to be a logical, level-headed, not overly dramatic patient.  Yet I keep leaning toward a BMX.  At times, I wonder if it's just too extreme, and I think it is--but I also worry so much about the anxiety of keeping one breast.  The tests, the waiting, the seemingly constant trips to the doctor for testing...it all feels, right now, like too much to bear.  Being an irreversible decision, though, makes it so hard.  I have been so healthy until now.  Rarely needed to see the doctor, had a textbook perfect pregnancy, labor, delivery, and breastfeeding experience.  Until I found the lump.  What I keep going to back to is that during a breast exam by my doctor at my 6 week post-partum check (6.5 months ago) there was nothing (to be felt).  Now, there is a tumor large enough to be felt and thought to be around 2ish+ cm.  That's some pretty rapid growth.    You were definitely lucky to have that time to think, and do chemo first.  That is not an option for me, I've asked.  They aren't comfortable with it.  I'm going to a large teaching hopital/major cancer center, which is considered pretty cutting edge for young women's breast cancer; there is a whole team dedicated to it.  They also do a lot of different studies, one of which I am already participating in.   I don't know that much about my cancer, I have an appointment on Friday where I hope to find out more.  This whole thing has been weird, and I think I haven't asked enough of the right questions, in spite of going in with a long list every time and reading everything I can get my hands on.  The tumor was diagnosed invasive Feb. 20th, so while they have not pressured me, they are now telling me I ought to get in to surgery, don't push it.  Which is why I scheduled it for the 11th.  It's been over 6 weeks now, and while I could take months to decide this, I am aware I shouldn't.  What  I do know is that it is thought to be around Stage II, no lymphatic involvement (according to images, but of course won't know for sure until surgery), Estrogen +, invasive ductal.  (I need to learn all the little abbreviations I see on here.)   Thank you all so much for your posts.  It helps a great deal.  Any more insight is definitely welcome.  Take care.

Posts.Content: jgisme wrote: Hello, I'm so grateful to have found this forum! I need some input from those who have walked this path before.  As we all know, anyone and everyone without breast cancer is eager to share an opnion.  I'd like to hear from someone who knows.   I was diagnosed in February with invasive, lobular, estrogen receptor positive cancer of the left breast.  I was breastfeeding at the time and had wean my daughter, which is why I am just now facing this decision.  I have opted for a mastectomy of the cancer-affected breast, with reconstruction.   However, I'm having a very difficult time deciding whether or not to have a bilateral mastectomy.  I realize my chances of acquiring cancer in the unaffected breast are actually pretty small.  I'd like to hear from anyone who opted for either a unilateral or bilateral mastectomy with cancer in only one side.  Any regrets?   Thanks so much for any input!
